```{.r .cell-code}
## load libraries
library(tidyverse)

```
:::


# 27MAR2024
Nauplii counting

Well-plate

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Well plate counts of freshly hatched artemia nauplii
A <- c(4,4,6,7,21,11)
B <- c(3,6,8,7,5,9)
C <- c(15,3,13,5,7,14)
D <- c(8,13,8,16,12,5)

# Sum each vector, and take the average
ml_nauplii <- mean(c(sum(A), sum(B), sum(C), sum(D)))
print(ml_nauplii)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 52.5
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Multiply it out by volume
# Each anemone gets 4mL of nauplii
ml_nauplii*4
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 210
```
:::
:::


## 29-MAR-2024

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Well plate counts of freshly hatched artemia nauplii
# counts represent 10uL volumes
A <- c(6,6,10,7,3,11)
B <- c(10,6,14,14,14,9)
C <- c(7,11,12,21,10,13)
D <- c(8,14,11,8,6,13)

naup <- data.frame(c(A, B, C, D)) %>%
  rename(counts = 1)

summary(naup)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
     counts     
 Min.   : 3.00  
 1st Qu.: 7.00  
 Median :10.00  
 Mean   :10.17  
 3rd Qu.:13.00  
 Max.   :21.00  
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
sd(naup$counts)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 3.897231
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Calculate coefficient of variation
cv <- sd(naup$counts) / mean(naup$counts) * 100

# Print result
print(cv)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 38.33342
```
:::
:::

So in 10uL we have 10 +/- 4 artemia... 
We have to multiply 10uL by 400 to get 4mL(4000uL) 
In 4mL we could have anywhere from $6*400 = 2,400$ to $10*400 = 4,000$ artemia
So, not ideal... because that means some anemones would be possibly getting twice as much as others. Sigh. Fuck. Stats. 

So I need a better way to consistently count the artemia... so that I'm getting a more accurate count/method of distributing equal numbers. SHIT. 

Ok going to use a stir plate and bar and try again

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Well plate counts of freshly hatched artemia nauplii
# counts represent 10uL volumes
A <- c(7,7,12,10,14,7)
B <- c(3,16,11,8,8,8)
C <- c(5,5,13,10,11,17)
D <- c(7,14,4,9,8,10)

naup <- data.frame(c(A, B, C, D)) %>%
  rename(counts = 1)

summary(naup)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
     counts      
 Min.   : 3.000  
 1st Qu.: 7.000  
 Median : 8.500  
 Mean   : 9.333  
 3rd Qu.:11.250  
 Max.   :17.000  
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
sd(naup$counts)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 3.667325
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Calculate coefficient of variation
cv <- sd(naup$counts) / mean(naup$counts) * 100

# Print result
print(cv)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 39.29277
```
:::
:::


Same result with stir bar as compared to hand stirring. Well shit, what next!?
But I don't want to count a larger volume that will take more time 
Fuck okay we'll go up to 20uL


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Well plate counts of freshly hatched artemia nauplii
# counts represent 20uL volumes
A <- c(18,24,25,30,31,25)
B <- c(32,27,29,27,24,19)
C <- c(24,31,34,21,27,26)
D <- c(31,28,30,33,26,28)

naup <- data.frame(c(A, B, C, D)) %>%
  rename(counts = 1)

summary(naup)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
     counts     
 Min.   :18.00  
 1st Qu.:24.75  
 Median :27.00  
 Mean   :27.08  
 3rd Qu.:30.25  
 Max.   :34.00  
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
sd(naup$counts)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 4.169419
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Calculate coefficient of variation
cv <- sd(naup$counts) / mean(naup$counts) * 100

# Print result
print(cv)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 15.39478
```
:::
:::

Whoo! Cut coefficient of variation in half baby! 
I'll fuckking take it. 

So. 20uL to 4mL, multiply by 200!
27+/-4 nauplii in 20uL, then there will be anywhere from $24*200=4,800$ and $31*200=6,200$ nauplii fed to each anemone. Good enough. If I wanted it to be narrower I'd probably have to increase the volume and therefore the time and difficulty of counting. I could do a whole analysis on the ideal volume of shrimp counting to minimize coefficient of variation and make really pretty plots! But no... I shan't be tempted... 

I CAN COUNT SHRIMP.
